strainDetails.notes: Cause urogenital syndromes like urethritis and cervicitis.

identity.biochemicalTests: Obligate intracellular bacterium; cannot be Gram-stained or cultured on standard media. Diagnosis relies on NAATs.

clinicalProfile.summary: Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common reportable bacterial sexually transmitted infection in the U.S. It causes a variety of clinical syndromes depending on the serovar, including urogenital infections (urethritis, cervicitis, PID), lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), and trachoma, the leading infectious cause of blindness worldwide.
pathophysiologyPearls: As an obligate intracellular parasite, C. trachomatis infects epithelial cells, leading to inflammation and tissue damage.
Many infections, particularly in women, are asymptomatic, which facilitates transmission and can lead to long-term complications like infertility if untreated.

clinicalSyndromes.description: Includes cervicitis, urethritis, and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Often asymptomatic.
A systemic STI characterized by a transient genital ulcer followed by painful inguinal and/or femoral lymphadenopathy (buboes).
A chronic keratoconjunctivitis endemic in resource-poor regions, leading to corneal scarring and blindness if untreated.
Can cause ophthalmia neonatorum (conjunctivitis) or pneumonia in infants born to infected mothers.

highRiskPopulations: Men who have sex with men (MSM)
Individuals with new or multiple sexual partners
Residents of or travelers to trachoma-endemic regions
transmissionVectors: Perinatal transmission from mother to infant
Flies and direct contact with ocular/nasal secretions (Trachoma)
prognosisNotes: Untreated urogenital infections can lead to PID, ectopic pregnancy, and infertility in women.
Re-infection is common; re-screening 3 months after treatment is recommended.

clinicalAlerts.details: Clinical failures are reported, and some studies suggest they are more common with single-dose azithromycin compared to a 7-day course of doxycycline, especially for rectal infections.
Exposure to penicillin-class antibiotics (e.g., amoxicillin in pregnancy) may induce a persistent, non-replicative state in the organism, potentially affecting treatment efficacy.

generalNotes: Doxycycline 100 mg PO BID for 7 days is the preferred regimen for most uncomplicated urogenital infections per 2021 CDC STI guidelines.
LGV requires a longer duration of treatment (3 weeks).
Treatment of all sexual partners from the preceding 60 days is recommended (Expedited Partner Therapy - EPT).

drugs.comments: May induce a persistent state in the organism.

testingIndications: Annual screening for all sexually active women <25 years.
Screening for older women and MSM with risk factors.
Evaluation of individuals with symptoms of STI (e.g., discharge, dysuria, pelvic pain).
Evaluation of neonates with conjunctivitis or pneumonia.
methodologyNotes: NAATs are the most sensitive tests for diagnosing C. trachomatis infections.
NAATs cannot distinguish between different serovars (e.g., D-K vs. L1-L3); PCR genotyping is required for this purpose.
NAATs can remain positive for up to 3 weeks after successful treatment due to the detection of non-viable organisms.

specialTests.purpose: To differentiate LGV serovars (L1-L3) from non-LGV serovars (D-K).

diagnosticNotes.summary: Diagnosis is primarily by NAAT on first-catch urine or swabs from the affected site (cervix, urethra, rectum, pharynx). Vaginal swabs (patient- or clinician-collected) are also highly sensitive.
diagnosticNotes.biosafetyWarning: Standard precautions are sufficient for handling clinical specimens.

methods.details: The gold standard for diagnosis due to high sensitivity and specificity. Can be performed on various specimen types.

preventionAndScreening.details: Annual screening is recommended for all sexually active women aged <25 years, as well as older women with risk factors (e.g., new or multiple sex partners). Screening of MSM is also advisable.
preventionAndScreening.targetPopulation: Sexually active women <25, at-risk older women, MSM.

treatmentLifecycle.details: Not routinely recommended, except in pregnancy. NAAT can remain positive for 2-3 weeks post-treatment.
Recommended for all treated individuals 3 months after treatment to detect re-infection.
All sexual contacts within the 60 days prior to diagnosis or symptom onset should be tested and treated. Expedited Partner Therapy (EPT) is an option.

antimicrobialStewardship: Doxycycline for 7 days is more effective than single-dose azithromycin for rectal chlamydial infections.

guidelineReferences.summaryOrNote: Review on screening for Chlamydia trachomatis.
Study on azithromycin efficacy in rectal infections.
RCT showing doxycycline is more effective for rectal chlamydia in MSM.
